    5-HT1A Receptor: An Old Target as a New Attractive Tool in Drug Discovery from Central Nervous System to Cancer

    • Ferdinando Fiorino*
      • , 
    • Beatrice Severino
      • , 
    • Elisa Magli
      • , 
    • Antonio Ciano
      • , 
    • Giuseppe Caliendo
      • , 
    • Vincenzo Santagada
      • , 
    • Francesco Frecentese
      • , and 
    • Elisa Perissutti
    View Author Information
    Dipartimento di Farmacia, Università degli Studi di Napoli “Federico II”, Via D. Montesano, 49, 80131, Napoli, Italy
    *Phone/Fax: +39(81)679825. E-mail: [email protected]
    Cite this: J. Med. Chem. 2014, 57, 11, 4407–4426
    Publication Date (Web):December 2, 2013

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    The serotonin receptor subtype 5-HT1A was one of the first serotonin receptor subtypes pharmacologically characterized. This receptor subtype has long been object of intense research and is implicated in the pathogenesis and treatment of anxiety and depressive disorders. In recent years, new chemical entities targeting the 5-HT1A receptor (alone or in combination with other molecular targets) have been proposed for novel therapeutic uses in neuroprotection, cognitive impairment, Parkinson’s disease, pain treatment, malignant carcinoid syndrome, and prostate cancer. This Perspective compares existing data on expression and signaling activity of the 5-HT1A receptor to a ligand with an intrinsic agonist or antagonist profile. Our purpose is also to make a complete overview, useful for underlining the features needed to select a specific pharmacological profile rather than another one. This aspect could be really interesting to consider and justify the 5-HT1A receptor as a new attractive target for drug discovery.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    5-Hydroxytryptamine (5-HT, Figure 1) was purified, crystallized, and named serotonin in 1948, the name being derived from the fact that the substance was produced in the serum (“ser”) and was found to limit or increase tone (“tonin”) in blood vessels. Although 5-HT is one of the most ancient neurotransmitters and appeared very early in evolution, its functions have been conserved and even expanded through the various branches of the evolutionary tree within the central and peripheral nervous systems. It plays a number of very important roles in normal brain function including modulation of mood states, hunger, sex, sleep, memory, emotion, anxiety, endocrine effects, and many others.(1)
    Serotonin receptors are widely expressed throughout the brain and in many key structures responsible for cognition and basic brain functions. As a local hormone, serotonin is present in numerous other tissues including the gastrointestinal tract and the cardiovascular and immune systems. This multiplicity of functions indicates that 5-HT is involved in a vast array of physiological and pathophysiological processes. This plethora of roles has fostered evaluation of many compounds as therapeutic tools in various pathological conditions, including antidepressants and antipsychotic and antiemetic drugs.
    The effects of 5-HT are mediated by a distinctive class of the G-protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) except for the 5-HT3 receptor, which is a cation channel. The GPCR 5-HT receptor family has been classified as a class A rhodopsin-like receptor.(2) There are six classes of GPCR 5-HT receptors, 5-HT1, 5-HT2, 5-HT4, 5-HT5, 5-HT6, and 5-HT7, with additional subclasses, amounting to fifteen receptors (Figure 2). Functional dissimilarities between the 5-HT classes are based on the stimulatory and inhibitory effect of the second messengers mediated through G proteins. The familiar structural topology includes seven-transmembrane domains (7-TM) together with a conserved “DRY” motif present at the cytoplasmic end of TM3 and the “NPxxY” motif at the TM7. Among these, one of the most important and extensively studied is the 5-HT1A receptor.

    5-HT1A Receptor: Characteristics, Distribution, and Biological Role

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The 5-HT1A receptor was the first among all the types of serotonin receptors to be cloned as an intronless genomic clone (G-21) of the human genome, which cross-hybridized with a full length β-adrenergic receptor probe at reduced stringency.(3) Sequence analysis of this genomic clone (to be later identified as the 5-HT1A receptor gene) indicated 43% amino acid homology with the β2-adrenergic receptor in the transmembrane domain. Moreover, while the gene was shown to be localized in chromosome 5 of the human genome and was thought to code for a potential member of the GPCR superfamily,(3) its identity as a serotonin receptor was discovered only later.(4) Membranes prepared from COS-1 cells transiently transfected with G-21 showed typical ligand binding characteristics of the 5-HT1A receptor. Subsequently, genes for the rat and mouse 5-HT1A receptors have been cloned and their amino acid sequences deduced.(5, 6) These developments facilitated stable expression and characterization of the receptor in a large number of neural and non-neural cell lines.(7-10) Furthermore, it was the first serotonin receptor for which polyclonal antibodies were obtained(4, 11) allowing their visualization at the subcellular level in various regions of the brain.
    The human gene for the 5-HT1A receptor encodes a protein of 422 amino acids with a core molecular weight of ∼46 000. Considering the presence of three consensus sequences for N-linked glycosylation on the amino terminus and the homology of the receptor with the β-adrenergic receptor, it is predicted that the receptor is oriented in the plasma membrane with an arrangement typical of the G-protein-coupled receptor superfamily.(12) Although the structure of the 5-HT1A receptor has not been experimentally determined yet, mutagenesis studies helped in identifying amino acid residues important for ligand binding and G-protein coupling.(13)
    5-HT1A receptors are broadly distributed in the CNS, being found in the soma, in dendrites, in some cases in the axon hillock of neurons, and in the cell body and processes of astrocytes. This receptor is expressed by all serotonin neurons (as an autoreceptor) and by many nonserotoninergic neurons (as a heteroreceptor). Recently the role of the 5-HT1A receptor in neural development was further disclosed,(14) indicating protection of stressed neuronal cells undergoing degeneration and apoptosis.(15) Moreover, localization of the 5-HT1A receptors in brain regions associated with learning and memory such as hippocampus, frontal cortex, and entorhinal cortex allows for direct and indirect modulation of multiple neurotransmitter systems involved in cognitive impairment.(16) In fact, 8-hydroxy-2-(di-N-propylamino)tetralin 1 (8-OH-DPAT, Figure 3), a 5-HT1A receptor agonist, is capable of impairing learning and memory in a range of rodent models including water maze, passive avoidance, radial maze, and delayed nonmatching to position. Moreover, studies in human volunteers have shown that oral administration of tandospirone 2 (a 5-HT1A agonist, Figure 3) impairs verbal memory.
    The 5-HT1A receptor not only contributes to the dynamic modulation of serotonergic activity affecting diverse functions such as cognition and emotion but also is thought to play a crucial role in the neuronal migration, neurite outgrowth, and synapse formation inherent to the neurodevelopmental process.(17) The 5-HT1A receptor represents a natural candidate crucial in an array of phenotypes. Among them, affective disorders and 5-HT1A receptor dysfunctions may play an important role in the genesis of major depressive disorder. Regarding the role of 5-HT1A receptor in anxiety, most of the knowledge comes from animal studies; mice with genetically inactivated 5-HT1A receptor gene develop an anxiety-like phenotype, reduced locomotor activity, and increased responsiveness to stress. Instead, mice with overexpressed 5-HT1A receptors display diminished anxiety when compared to the wild-type animals.(18) Schizophrenia is a life long, complex psychotic disorder, and the introduction of antipsychotic drugs, identified as D2 antagonists (i.e., chloropromazine 3, thiethylperazine 4, Figure 4), in the late 1950s was a major advance in the management of this pathology. Unfortunately, blockade of D2 receptors accounts for severe side effects, in particular extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) and hyperprolactinemia, that undermine compliance. It tooks nearly 3 decades to obtain drugs that cause no or minimal EPS at therapeutically relevant doses. These second-generation derivatives, characterized by combined D2 and 5-HT2A antagonism (i.e., olanzapine 5, clozapine 6, quetiapine 7, risperidone 8, Figure 4), were defined as atypical, in contrast to conventional D2 blockers. Finally, another pharmacological approach, which has been steadily gaining approval, involves the combination of D2 antagonism and 5-HT1A agonism in the same molecule(19) (i.e., perospirone 9, F-15063 10, SLV-313 11, Figure 4).
    Regarding the role of the 5-HT1A receptor in Parkinson’s disease, it has been demonstrated that, acting as presynaptic receptor, 5-HT1A can decrease the release of a range of neurotransmitters including glutamate and dopamine (DA). While acting as postsynaptic receptor, it exerts an inhibitory effect by hyperpolarizing neurons. In agreement with the proposed role, 5-HT1A agonists reduce L-DOPA-induced dyskinesia (LID), even if several questions regarding the mechanism of action of 5-HT1A agonists in reducing dyskinesia and potential worsening of parkinsonism are still open.(20) The 5-HT1A receptor subtype has also been reported to play a role in nociception, and currently, it is investigated as the target of an analgesic, befiradol 12 (Figure 5), that has entered the clinical phase of development.(11, 21)
    These results are in agreement with data suggesting the presence of 5-HT1A receptors in peripheral terminals of primary sensory afferent fibers. Accordingly, several lines of electrophysiological, pharmacological, and biochemical evidence have shown that 5-HT1A receptors are present in primary afferent neurons.(22) 5-HT1A, 5-HT1C, 5-HT2, 5-HT3, and 5-HT4 receptors have also been identified in the gut, either in the enteric nervous system or on smooth muscle cells. The actions of 5-HT1A and 5-HT1C may include inhibition of release and contraction of smooth muscle.(23) 5-HT acts as a cell growth factor and is capable of promoting the proliferation of LNCap, a prostate cancer cell line, in a dose-dependent manner and affords similar results on the PC-3 and DU145 cell lines.(24) Numerous studies suggest that the 5-HT1A receptor subtype in the medullary raphe (MR) mediates protective responses to stress. Systemic administration of 1 induces bradycardia and a decrease in blood pressure, suggesting that the 5-HT1A receptor has an inhibitory effect on sympathetic outflow. Similar sympatholytic effects were evident when 1 was administered via microinjection directly to select nuclei of the MR. The 5-HT1A receptor also mediates the cardiovascular responses to other stressors such as conditioned fear, fever induction, and psychological stress.(25) These data suggest that the inhibitory action of 5-HT1A receptor in the MR reduces the activity of neurons, mediating the cardiovascular responses to various forms of stress. Recently the role of serotoninergic receptors in sexual function was confirmed. In fact, 5-HT1A receptors are able to decrease ejaculatory latency time and erection in male rats, while 5-HT2C receptors have opposite functions.(26-28) Finally, other studies show possible connections between serotoninergic receptors and sexual hormones. Thus, in the presence of a sexually receptive female, the blood testosterone level increases in male mice; this effect is blocked by administering a 5-HT1A receptor agonist.(29, 30) The other antagonistic hormone, estradiol, was reported to induce a desensitization of the 5-HT1A receptors.(31, 32)

    5-HT1A and the CNS

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    As reported above, 5-HT1A receptors are distributed throughout the CNS with an enrichment of presynaptic 5-HT1A autoreceptors in the raphe nucleus and in several postsynaptic regions, such as the hippocampic and cortical areas. These receptors play a crucial role in the control of 5-HT release, and 5-HT1A agonists seem to be effective in treatment of anxiety and depression states and in the therapy of pain and schizophrenia. Their efficacy in neuroprotection and stroke treatment has recently been confirmed.

    5-HT1A and Anxiety

    In order to validate the correlation between 5-HT1A receptor and anxiety, azapirone derivatives (i.e., buspirone 13, Buspar), acting as 5-HT1A receptor full and partial agonists, have been developed as novel anxiolytic agents that are not associated with the dependence and the side effect profile of benzodiazepines.(1) Compound 13, discovered and approved as an anxiolytic in the 1980s, was initially investigated as a putative antipsychotic agent devoid of the typical side effects of that drug class. When it lacked therapeutic utility in schizophrenia, further study showed that 13, administered in single dose, had a marked taming effect on aggressive monkeys, and its chronic administration reversed stress-induced behavior in several animal models of anxiety.(33) The launch of 13 led to the preparation of several N4-(2-pyrimidinyl)piperazines containing a N1-imidobutyl substituent, as a potential new generation of anxiolytic agents, such as 2 (Sediel marketed in China and Japan), gepirone 14, and ipsapirone 15 (Figure 6). In these derivatives, the 1-(2-pyrimidinyl)piperazine, the tail of the molecule, and the heterocyclic head are linked to an alkyl chain that hardly affects the 5-HT1A affinity. Functional assays have demonstrated that these compounds act as partial agonists. Successively, the replacement of the 1-(2-pyrimidinyl)piperazine moiety with a 1-(2-methoxyphenyl)piperazine moiety led to BMY-8227, 17. High 5-HT1A affinity is maintained by replacement of the azaspirodecanedione nucleus of 17 with an N-phthalimido group that led to NAN-190 18 (Figure 6).(34) This compound was found to be nonselective, and shortening the alkyl chain length to three or two units significantly decreases the affinity. On the basis of these results, N-1-substituted N-4-arylpiperazines (so-called “long-chain arylpiperazines”) have been extensively studied as a structural element useful in designing 5-HT1A receptor ligands. The general formula of these compounds presents a 1-arylpiperazine moiety linked via an alkyl chain of variable length to a terminal fragment (imides, amides, alkyl, arylalkyl, or heteroarylalkyl derivatives and tetralines). Moreover, the identification of these new ligands as 5-HT1A receptor agonists led to the definition of the generally accepted 5-HT1A agonist pharmacophore, in which an aromatic ring and a coplanar basic nitrogen atom are two of the structural features required for ligand recognition.
    The distance between the aromatic center and the basic nitrogen is optimal at 5.2 Å, with the amino group 0.2 Å above the plane of the aromatic moiety. Finally, the electron lone pair is almost perpendicular to the plane of the aromatic ring (Figure 7).(35)
    Thereafter, a number of 5-HT1A agonists have shown anxiolytic activities in various animal models, such as the Vogel or Gellar–Seifter conflict test, the elevated-plus maze, light–dark and conditioned-fear paradigms, and the anti-marble-burying behavior test. The involvement and crucial role of the postsynaptic 5-HT1A receptor in limbic areas in regulating anxiety have been supported by numerous studies. In recent years, some of the novel compounds acting at 5-HT1A receptors have entered phase II and phase III clinical trials or are already commercially available as anxiolytics (14 and S-15535 19, MN-305 20, flesinoxan 21, alnespirone 22, lesopitron 23; Figure 8).(36) The structural feature characterizing most of these promising compounds is the arylpiperazine scaffold.(35) The influence of each part of the arylpiperazine group on the 5-HT1A receptor affinity, intrinsic activity, and selectivity has been the subject of many structure–activity relationship (SAR) studies . In particular, much effort has been devoted to understand the role of the terminal part in the ligand–receptor interaction, and in consequence, a great number of many different fragments have been used.(37) However, a limitation of many 5-HT1A receptor ligands for their potential use as drugs or pharmacological tools is their undesired high affinity for other receptors. The dopaminergic D2 receptor and α1-adrenoceptor are two examples of receptors for which several 5-HT1A ligands show high affinity. However, there has been an ongoing effort to develop more selective 5-HT1A ligands in order to have novel pharmacological tools that could improve our knowledge of the signal transduction mechanism and lead to compounds with high affinity and selectivity.

    5-HT1A and Depressive Disorder

    5-HT1A agonists show significant antidepressant activity in various animal models such as tail suspension test and forced swimming test.(38) Although the precise mechanism responsible for the antidepressant action of 5-HT1A agonists is still uncertain, desensitization or down-regulation of presynaptic 5-HT1A receptors has been proposed to be implicated in this pharmacological effect.(39) Specifically, repeated treatment with a 5-HT1A agonist desensitizes presynaptic 5-HT1A receptors in the raphe nuclei, which disengages 5-HT neurons from autoreceptor-mediated inhibition.(39-41) As a consequence, 5-HT neurons are activated by chronic treatment with 5-HT1A agonists, and this counteracts the 5-HT deficit in depression. It has been proposed that combination therapy with a 5-HT1A agonist or antagonist would be expected to speed up the effect of serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), which represent the first-line treatment of depression. In particular, a 5-HT1A antagonist can improve the efficacy of SSRIs by blocking inhibitory 5-HT1A autoreceptors. Likewise, a 5-HT1A agonist could have antidepressant-like activity by triggering postsynaptic 5-HT1A receptors and/or producing a faster desensitization of 5-HT1A autoreceptors. There is also evidence that 5-HT1A partial agonism, combined with 5-HT reuptake inhibition, can produce antidepressant-like effects. As example, vilazodone 24, the prototype of SSRI/5-HT1A partial agonist, was approved in 2011 by the FDA for use in the treatment of major depressive disorders.(42) Similarly flibanserin 25, DU-125530 26, and OPC-14523 27 (Figure 8) have reached late stage clinical development as antidepressant drugs.
    The LCAPs BMY 7378 (compound 16, Figure 6) and 18 (Figure 6) represent a generation of 5-HT1A receptor antagonists possessing postsynaptic antagonist character but also behaving as low-efficacy partial agonists.(43) Successively a second generation of 5-HT1A antagonists (Figure 9) have been developed which include WAY-100135 28, WAY-100635 29, and S(−)-UH-301 30 (a compound related to 1). These compounds act as 5-HT1A antagonists both at presynaptic and postsynaptic level and are also called “silent” 5-HT1A receptor antagonists.(43, 44) Their development should provide interesting and promising improvements in 5-HT1A research. For example, pretreatment of patients with 5-HT1A antagonists accelerates the effects of selective SSRIs and enhances their clinical efficacy as antidepressants. A new LCAP, LY-426965 31 (Figure 9), more metabolically stable and with a better oral bioavailability than 29, in combination with fluoxetine (Prozac), increases extracellular levels of 5-HT beyond that achievable by fluoxetine alone. This combination is being examined for the treatment of depression and as a smoking cessation agent.(45-47) The therapeutic potential of 5-HT1A antagonists is quite intriguing.
    By comparison of the structural features of several 5-HT1A antagonists, it is possible to derive a basic pharmacophore of the recognition site(48) that contains the same elements as the agonist pharmacophore, represented by an aromatic nucleus and a basic nitrogen atom (Figure 7). In this model the mean distance between the center of the aromatic ring and the nitrogen atom is 5.6 Å while this nitrogen is lying at 1.6 Å above the plane defined by the reference ring.

    5-HT1A and Schizophrenia

    In the field of schizophrenia, 5-HT1A receptor could represent another important opportunity for the medicinal chemist. In fact, as mentioned above, its activation was found to reduce motor side effects induced by activation of D2 receptors. Thus, the new approach can involve the combination of D2 antagonism and 5-HT1A agonism in the same molecule. Compound 9 (Figure 4) and ziprasidone 32 (Figure 10) are two valuable examples of this multitarget strategy that reached the market in 2001 and 2002, respectively. Among many other agents with a similar pharmacological profile, 11 (Figure 4) and bifeprunox 33 (Figure 10) entered respectively phase I and phase III clinical trials.(36) There is still clinical demand of newer antipsychotic drugs against positive and negative symptoms, cognitive impairments, and affective disorders. It has been proposed that 5-HT1A agonists can alleviate antipsychotic-induced EPS by stimulating postsynaptic 5-HT1A receptors in the striatum and cerebral cortex,(49) probably through nondopaminergic mechanisms.(50)
    Even in the field of 5-HT1A agonists employed in the therapy of schizophrenia, the long-chain arylpiperazines represent an important class of derivatives that are able to modulate dopamine and serotonin receptors. Aripiprazole 34 (Abilify, Figure 11), approved by the FDA in November 2002 for the treatment of schizophrenia, is one of the most representative compounds. Successively different series of 1-arylpiperazine derivatives, structurally related to 34, were developed.(51) These compounds were designed to improve resistance to CYP-oxidative metabolism or to afford metabolites devoid of CNS activity at D2, 5-HT1A, and 5-HT2A receptors. The most representative compounds are characterized by a benzoxazine scaffold, and in particular the 3-oxo-3,4-dihydro-2H-benzo[b][1,4]oxazine derivatives (Figure 11) showed nanomolar affinity for all the target receptors.(52) The development of some analogues of 34 (Figure 11) by Pfizer Inc.(53) led to interesting results. In particular, compound 35 displayed a pharmacological profile comparable to that of 34. Another series of classical long-chain arylpiperazine (or homopiperazine) derivatives incorporates a quinolinylamide as the terminal fragment. The compounds belonging to this class were able to modulate dopamine and serotonin receptors (Figure 11).(54) The antipsychotic potential of these compounds was evaluated in the MK-801 (dizocilpine) hyperactivity model. The administration of MK-801 in rodents and humans elicits schizophrenia-like symptoms characterized by hyperlocomotion and stereotyped behavior, which are reverted by antipsychotic drugs. Selected compounds were able to significantly reduce MK-801-induced hyperactivity at a minimal effective dose (MED) of 10 mg/kg.
    Another interesting class of LCAPs, represented by indolizine compounds (Figure 12), was reported as a new series of atypical antipsychotics. The compounds were screened at D2, 5-HT1A, and 5-HT2A receptors, and the data disclosed indicated that the derivatives embodying a 1-(2,3-dichlorophenyl)piperazine group had better affinity profiles toward all the target receptors (especially for the 5-HT2A receptor) than those of the other substituted arylpiperazine derivatives. Moreover, the different position of the alkyl chain on the distal indolizine nucleus showed a limited influence on dopamine D2, D3, and D4 and serotonin 5-HT1A receptor affinities whereas it had a more marked influence on 5-HT2A affinity. The intrinsic activity at D2 receptors was assessed for selected compounds that behaved as full antagonists or partial agonists.(55)

    5-HT1A and Pain

    5-HT1A receptors are also targeted by new analgesic substances. In fact, the possible correlation of the peripheral 5-HT1 receptors producing antinociception in the formalin test with the 5-HT1A receptor subtype is established, in the first instance, by the use of 29 (Figure 9), a highly potent and selective 5-HT1A antagonist (pIC50 = 8.87 ± 0.14; pA2 = 9.71).(56) At doses devoid of any effects on formalin-induced nociceptive behavior, this compound significantly blocked the antinociceptive effect of the 5-HT1A receptor agonist R(+)-UH-301 36 (Figure 13).(57)
    Recent studies in knockout mice showed that 5-HT1A receptors mediate an endogenous inhibitory control of heat-evoked nociception.(58) Currently 12, a highly selective and efficient 5-HT1A agonist (Figure 5) that (as already reported) has entered phase III clinical development,(11, 21) is being studied as an analgesic. Therefore, the correlation between 5-HT1A receptors and 5-HT1A agonists as antinociceptive could represent another important opportunity for the medicinal chemist that could stimulate new efforts to develop 5-HT1A agonists possessing analgesic properties, including efficacy in neuropathic pain models.

    5-HT1A and Neuroprotection

    Neuroprotection and stroke treatment could represent another interesting opportunity for 5-HT1A ligands. Activation of 5-HT1A receptors exerts a neuroprotective effect in different animal models of ischemia. The potential of 5-HT1A agonists for the treatment of ischemic brain disorders was revealed by several studies started in 1990. In particular, 1, 13, 14, and 15 were tested in rat and mouse after induction of focal cerebral ischemia, demonstrating their efficacy in decreasing the area of cerebral damage. In gerbils 1 reduced hippocampal cell damage induced by transient global ischemia. This was found to correlate with a reduced phosphorylation of the NMDA receptor NR1 subunit and with prevention of the marked reduction of hippocampal brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) levels elicited by global ischemia. 5-HT1A receptor activation by 1 has been also associated with neuroprotection against NMDA-induced apoptotic cell death in cell cultures.(59) Other studies have shown that 5-HT1A receptor stimulation protects against ischemic neuronal cell death.(60) The cellular mechanisms underlying the neuroprotective effect of 5-HT1A receptor activation remain unclear. One of the proposed mechanisms is the hyperpolarization of pyramidal neurons that inhibits the excitotoxicity of glutamate after cerebral ischemia. Previous studies have shown that 5-HT1A receptor stimulation can modulate NMDA receptor-induced Ca2+ influx, and other reports have provided evidence for functional interactions between NMDA channels and 5-HT1A receptors. These results suggest that 5-HT1A receptors may serve as mediators of autoprotective mechanisms of the brain against the effects of excitatory amino acid overstimulation.(61) In fact, the 5-HT1A receptors are coupled to Gi/Go proteins to mediate a range of biological effects, especially negative modulation of adenylate cyclase and cAMP formation, which subsequently reduces the phosphorylation of ion channels and thereby neuronal excitation.(62) It should be noted that 1 prevents the ischemia-induced increase in NR1 subunit phosphorylation, but total levels of the NR1 subunit remain unchanged, indicating that the increase in phosphorylated NR1 subunit was not a consequence of an increase in total NR1 levels. Administration of the agonist 1 prevented a decrease in BDNF levels, and this might play a crucial role in the protection against ischemia-induced delayed pyramidal neuronal death in the CA1 subfield of hippocampus. It is known that global ischemia induces expression of activated caspase-3 which activates a host of downstream events leading to fragmentation of genomic DNA, a hallmark of apoptotic cell death.(63) It was found that NMDA-induced caspase-3 activity and DNA fragmentation were almost completely blocked by 1 in cell cultures.(59) These protective effects were reversed by pretreatment with the antagonist 29. The antiapoptotic properties of 5-HT1A receptor stimulation against excitotoxic insult as well as the protective effect of 1 on ischemia-induced hippocampal cell damage might be related, among others, to a facilitated antiapoptotic effect of neurotrophin BDNF. It is known that 5-HT and BDNF often function in a cooperative manner to regulate neuronal plasticity and survival. Activation of 5-HT receptors coupled to cAMP production and CREB (cAMP response element-binding protein) activation can induce transcription of the BDNF gene, but interestingly, it was also found that serotonin acting on 5-HT1A autoreceptors increases BDNF expression.(64) It was definitely demonstrated that 5-HT1A receptor stimulation could represent a useful therapeutic approach for modulating apoptotic events in neurodegenerative processes. The development of selective 5-HT1A agonists could lead to useful neuroprotective agents able to interfere with excitotoxic and apoptotic cell death processes in the postischemic brain.

    5-HT1A and Parkinson’s Disease

    Treatment with l-3,4-dihydroxyphenylalanine (L-DOPA) is currently the main therapy for Parkinson’s disease (PD).(65) However, patients receiving long treatments may develop motor complications, such as dyskinesia. The underlying mechanism of L-DOPA-induced dyskinesia (LID) is complex, and several pathways are involved in the development of this side effect.(66)
    Among these there is an abnormal 5-HT-mediated neurotransmission, since 5-HT1A receptors are localized both pre- and postsynaptically. Presynaptic 5-HT1A receptors reduce the release of several neurotransmitters, such as glutamate and dopamine. Postsynaptic 5-HT1A receptors hyperpolarize neurons exerting an inhibitory effect.(67, 68) Treatment with 1 (Figure 3) reduces dyskinesia in both the 6-hydroxydopamine (6-OHDA) lesioned rat and 1-methyl-4-phenyl-1,2,3,6-tetrahydropyridine (MPTP) lesioned primate, confirming the involvement of 5-HT1A receptors in LID. However, in the MPTP-lesioned primate, R-(+)-8-OH-DPAT 37 (Figure 14) also reduces the antiparkinsonian benefit of L-DOPA.(69) The same effect is obtained following treatment with the 5-HT1A partial agonist 2 (Figure 3). Sarizotan 38 (Figure 14), a 5-HT1A receptor agonist, reduces dyskinesia in parkinsonian rats and monkeys.(70) In phase II studies, 38 reduced LID but increased duration of off-time, i.e., exacerbated parkinsonism, at high doses. However, 38 did not show an antidyskinetic effect in phase III trials.(71)
    Several studies have focused on elucidation of the mechanism by which 5-HT1A agonists reduce dyskinesia and worsen parkinsonism. Some of the reported evidence suggests that typical 5-HT1A agonists also act as antagonists toward D2 receptors,(72) and some 5-HT1A ligands, described as full agonists, are actually partial 5-HT1A agonists. It is thus not clear whether the antidyskinetic properties are truly related to 5-HT1A stimulation or whether the potential to reduce antiparkinsonian benefit comes from another mechanism because D2 receptor antagonists will alleviate dyskinesia, albeit at the expense of worsening parkinsonism. Understanding the pathophysiology of dyskinesia could be very important for the development of novel and useful therapeutics. The relevant role played by the 5-HT1A receptors in developing dyskinesia was confirmed by a recent study that has shown how parkinsonian animals treated chronically with L-DOPA have increased levels of 5-HT1A receptors in the striatal matrix. 5-HT1A agonists are potentially able to reduce dyskinesia. The challenge in developing such compounds appears to be to deliver this potential antidyskinetic effect without compromising the antiparkinsonian benefit. This might be obtained by stimulating striatal 5-HT1A receptors and/or those in middle layers of cortex without involving the 5-HT1A receptors in external cortical layers. This selective effect might be achieved within a specific therapeutic window, using compounds with partial agonist efficacy, or with 5-HT1A agonists exhibiting a specific anatomical selectivity. It is noteworthy that this kind of selectivity has already been described for the 5-HT1A agonist F15599 39, (pKi = 8.65 ± 0.11; pEC50 = 6.41 ± 0.06; Figure 14), which shows selectivity of action for one brain region over another.(73)
    Eltoprazine 40 (Figure 14), a mixed 5-HT1A/1B receptor agonist, was found to be highly effective in reducing LID in rat and monkey models of PD. Also in this case, the antidyskinetic effect is associated with a partial loss of the therapeutic effect of l-DOPA. Moreover, it was also demonstrated that 40, given at a low dose, can be used to potentiate the antidyskinetic effect of amantadine 41 (Figure 14). Compound 40, in contrast to 38, can be used at lower doses because the simultaneous activation of both the 5-HT1A and the 5-HT1B receptors causes a synergistic effect on silencing of serotonin neurons induced by activation of both autoreceptor subtypes.(74, 75) In addition, 38 is known to antagonize D2 receptors, which may also contribute to the side effects observed in patients. In contrast, 40 has no antidopaminergic activity as demonstrated by the fact that the drug was not significantly effective against dyskinesia induced by apomorphine. On this basis, 40, which is currently in clinical trials, may have a significantly better chance to become a drug. The ongoing clinical trials will help to verify whether the reduction of serotonin neuron activity obtained by treatment with 5-HT1A receptor agonists may lead not only to a reduction of dyskinesia but also to a partial loss of the therapeutic efficacy of L-DOPA. In this scenario, a combination of low doses of 40 with 41 may offer an alternative approach to improve antidyskinetic efficacy while reducing the side effects of the treatment. Thus, patients under 41 treatment may be ideal candidates for recruitment into clinical studies investigating the antidyskinetic efficacy of 40.(76)
    The BMY-14802 42 (Figure 14), another 5-HT1A receptor agonist at an effective, antidyskinetic dose, did not alter L-DOPA’s efficacy in improving stepping in lesioned animals. Moreover, 42 was found to attenuate dyskinesia produced by direct D1 and D2 receptor agonists, thereby indicating antidyskinetic efficacy against a broad spectrum of DA replacement therapies. Finally, antidyskinetic effects of 42, against L-DOPA but not direct toward DA receptor agonists, were reversed by the 5-HT1A antagonist 29 (Figure 9). These results represent an extension of previous studies(77) that showed the antidyskinetic potential of 42 against LID at a dose range that is effective in reducing LID and contralateral rotations. More importantly, an antidyskinetic efficacy for 42 in attenuating dyskinesia produced by the direct DA receptor agonists SKF81297 43 and quinpirole 44 (Figure 14) was demonstrated.(78) In agreement with these considerations, the antidyskinetic profile of 42 is similar to that of 5-HT1A agonists, like 13, 1, 2 (Figure 3), and piclozotan 45 (IC50 = 0.47nM; Figure 14) that have been shown to be effective in reducing dyskinesia both in humans and in animal models. Despite the early success of several 5-HT1A agonists, this class of compounds was not always successful in PD patients because their use was associated with increased extrapyramidal PD symptoms.(79) However, it has been firmly established that 42 does not bind with high affinity to the D1 and D2 receptors (IC50 values of >1000 and 6430 nM, respectively) and at the tested dose provides antidyskinetic relief without reducing antiparkinsonian efficacy.

    5-HT1A and Sexual Function

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Anatomically, sexual reflexes are mixed (somatic–autonomic) circuits represented by emission (sympathetic center and somatic afferents), expulsion (parasympathetic center and somatic efferents), and erection (parasympathetic center and somatic afferents). Physiologically, ejaculation has a dual autonomic mediation consisting of two distinct and opposite autonomic centers (emission and expulsion), both of them with a positive contribution to the respective function.(26) Experimentally, 5-HT has two distinct, opposite, and positive effects on sexual function; via 5-HT1A receptors (5-HT1A agonists) it decreases intravaginal ejaculatory latency and erection, and via 5-HT2C receptors (5-HT2C agonists) it increases both erection and ejaculatory latency.(27) Consequently it appears clear that one type of serotonin receptor would have a stimulating effect on sexual function while the other one would have an inhibitory sexual effect. Another possibility is that both types of serotonin receptors could positively modulate sexual function. The 5-HT1A receptors could directly promote the sympathetic emission (shortening intravaginal ejaculatory latency times (IELT), as in premature emission after spinal cord injury) and could also indirectly decrease the opposite parasympathetic expulsion/erection centers (a decreased participation of erection and expulsion).(80) The 5-HT2C agonists would directly favor parasympathetic expulsion and erection (an increased erection) and consequently (indirectly) would inhibit the sympathetic (emission) center that starts ejaculation (increased IELT).(80)
    A correlation between 5-HT1A and 5-HT2C receptors has been demonstrated by recent studies. Administration of a 5-HT2C agonist induces bursts of rhythmic activity in sympathetic nerves to the vas deferens in male rats, while 5-HT1A receptor agonists do not show such a response. The coadministration of a 5-HT1A agonist with a 5-HT2C agonist induces an enhancement of the vas deferens response.(28) Thus, the two agonists act in the lumbosacral spinal cord and the 5-HT2C receptors play a central role in ejaculation. In humans, the administration of drugs targeting the 5-HT2C receptors (e.g., paroxetine, which indirectly stimulates 5-HT2C activity by increasing levels of serotonin in the synapse) delays ejaculation, and this effect was reversed by drugs which stimulate the 5-HT1A receptors (e.g., 13).(81)
    In the mating behavior test in rats, a significant reduction of intromission frequency, IELT, and interval after ejaculation can be achieved by the administration of 1. By use of the mounting test with genital anesthesia, no effect of this drug was reported. In the ex copula test, 1 dramatically inhibits ejaculation and the display of penile erection.(82) These complex results might be the consequence of the fact that libido and sexual arousal (cerebral ejaculation) could be induced by the action of complex afferents, represented by an association of genital somatic afferents with psychic/sensorial impulses. The administration of 1 followed by evaluation of sexual responses in male dogs (ejaculation, penile erection, and pelvic thrusting behavior) showed a dose-dependent decrease in the amount of ejaculated semen, possibly through indirect inhibition of parasympathetic expulsion/erection center (in fact this drug also exhibits an adverse effect on erectile response). However, at the highest doses, 1 produces an increase in IELT in dogs and a decrease in IELT in rats.(29) Explanations for these opposite responses are required. Hypoactive sexual desire disorder (HSDD) represents a persistent or recurrent deficiency or absence of sexual fantasies and desire, and it causes marked distress or interpersonal difficulty. This dysfunction should not be exclusively correlated to other psychiatric disorders (except another sexual dysfunction) or to the physiological effects of a single endogenous substance or to general pathological conditions. A cross-sectional, demographically representative U.S. population-based survey, conducted in 2006, found that approximately 1 in 10 premenopausal women reported low sexual desire with associated distress, typical of HSDD.(83) HSDD is believed to be the most common form of female sexual dysfunction but remains underdiagnosed and undertreated. Recently, 25 (Figure 8), a well-known serotonergic agent, has been reported to be efficacious in premenopausal women with HSDD and has an ongoing clinical development program in this population.(84, 85) The positive actions of 25 on sexual functioning were first discovered serendipitously while studying this agent in patients with major depressive disorder. Compound 25 was ineffective as an antidepressant, but it increased scores in women on the Arizona sexual experiences scale,(86) thus leading to further formal clinical evaluations in HSDD. Compound 25 has multifunctional actions unlike most other therapeutic agents in clinical practice. It shows the highest affinity for 5-HT1A and 5-HT2A receptors, where it acts as agonist and antagonist, respectively.(87-90) Compound 25 binds to additional receptors with affinities within 1 order of magnitude of that for 5-HT1A receptors. These include 5-HT2C receptors (antagonistic action), 5-HT2B receptors (antagonistic action), and D4 receptors where it acts as either an antagonist or a weak agonist, depending on the model system used for testing.(86) Compound 25 shows a pharmacologic profile of 5-HT1A agonism/5-HT2A antagonism with consequent synergistic actions on pyramidal neurons in the prefrontal cortex (PFC). Through these receptors, 5-HT can profoundly influence the release of glutamate from the PFC pyramidal neurons innervating monoamine brainstem centers downstream and thus change the amount of 5-HT, norepinephrine (NE), and DA being released by these monoamine centers. As already demonstrated by neuroimaging studies of patients with HSDD, changes in PFC neuronal functioning are correlated to altered neuronal firing rates of certain pyramidal neurons and probably are responsible for HSDD. According to these studies, low desire may be expressed in women as an inability to attend to sexual cues.(91) Consequently the symptoms of HSDD may be balanced by increasing DA and NE levels and improving the efficiency of information processing of these pyramidal neurons.
    In conclusion, 25 is a postsynaptic 5-HT1A agonist/5-HT2A antagonist that enhances DA and NE activity and reduces 5-HT activity in certain brain regions.(92) It has been hypothesized that the drug acts by redressing neurotransmitter imbalances thought to contribute to the low sexual desire of women with HSDD.(92) Unfortunately at the end of 2010, 25 received a negative report by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, and consequently its development could be stopped. Finally GSK-958108 (structure not disclosed)(93) represents a novel 5-HT1A antagonist, which is being investigated by GlaxoSmithKline for the treatment of primary premature ejaculation.

    5-HT1A and Cardiovascular Response

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Numerous studies suggest that the 5-HT1A receptor subtype in the MR mediates protective responses to stress.(94, 95) Systemic administration of 1 (Figure 3) leads to bradycardia and a decrease in blood pressure suggesting that the 5-HT1A receptor has an inhibitory effect on sympathetic outflow. Moreover 1 reduces the cutaneous vasoconstriction evoked by physical stressors such as cold exposure or fever, conditioned fear,(95) and psychological stress.(96) To assess the role of 5-HT1A receptor subtype on these effects, microinjection of 29 (5-HT1A antagonist, Figure 9) in the MR reverses the inhibition of cold-evoked cutaneous vasoconstriction induced by 1.(97) Thus, the MR is proved to be the site where 5-HT1A receptors can mediate stress-evoked cardiac or cutaneous vasoconstrictor responses.(97-99) At the same time, activation of 5-HT1A receptors located in higher brain regions, such as limbic ones, may also reduce stress-evoked cardiovascular responses via an anxiolytic effect rather than via a direct effect on brainstem cardiovascular neurons.(100) In addition to the inhibition mediated by activation of central 5-HT1A receptors, cardiovascular responses evoked by acute psychological stress, cold exposure, or fever could also be mediated by neurons within the dorsomedial hypothalamus (DMH), a region implicated in limbic and thermoregulatory functions.(101-103) Furthermore, the cardiovascular responses evoked by disinhibition of neurons in the DMH of anesthetized rats are also powerfully inhibited by systemic administration of 1, and these effects are completely reversed by subsequent administration of 29.(104) In transgenic 5-HT1A knockout models of mice it was found that the cardiovascular responses are exacerbated when the animals are exposed to stressful stimuli. These data suggested that the inhibitory effect of 5-HT1A receptor in the MR reduces the activity of neurons that help mediate the cardiovascular responses to various forms of stress.(105) In addition, the possible role of the raphe pallidus nuclei (NRP) in mediating the same cardiovascular responses to several types of stress in conscious rats was explored. It was hypothesized that pharmacological inhibition of the NRP and selective activation of the inhibitory 5-HT1A receptor would block the sympatho-excitation associated with the cardiovascular response to various forms of environmental stress.
    Quite independently, studies in the central control of the autonomic nervous system showed that systemic 5-HT1A receptor stimulation can give rise to sympathetic inhibition that does not affect the baroreflex or chemoreflex,(104) but it does suppress responses evoked from the DMH.(104, 106) Since sympathetic responses to all of these challenges can be attenuated at the level of the MR through 5-HT1A stimulation and since systemic 5-HT1A activation can also reduce sympathetic responses to physical and psychological stressors (i.e., cold exposure, inflammatory, air jet, open field, restraint, and social stress),(97-99, 107) it has been widely assumed that the 5-HT1A agonists could represent useful therapeutic agents for reducing all those sympathetic responses that occur in some forms of hypertension and heart failure.(99) There is the possibility that systemic doses that are just sufficient to produce anxiolytic effects may reduce the sympathetic drive indirectly by an action at more rostral, purely limbic sites. In fact, doses that are sufficient to decrease the sympathetic responses to psychological stress are not enough to perturbate physical nature stress responses. Indeed it was demonstrated that at 0.25 mg/kg dose, 1 reduces the sympathetic responses to all emotional stressors but not to cold exposure. Definitely, the abolition of the cardiovascular responses to stress by administration of 1 into the NRP suggested that these responses were largely mediated by serotonergic neurotransmission and that NRP is responsible for mediation of protective cardiovascular responses to exogenous stress, most likely via the 5-HT1A receptor subtype.(100)
    Another correlation between 5-HT1A receptors and cardiovascular responses could be represented by treatment of hyperphagia and obesity with coadministration of a 5-HT1A agonist (21, Figure 8) and an inhibitor of noradrenalin uptake (sibutramine). The reduction in food intake produced by sibutramine is largely due to increased noradrenergic activity through the central α1-adrenoceptors that can also cause an increased cardiovascular activity. A report suggests that when a 5-HT1A agonist (21) is combined with sibutramine, sibutramine-induced hypertension and tachycardia are attenuated. Surprisingly, the administration of 21 alone and at its maximally effective oral dose (2.5 mg/kg) does not produce significant effects on blood pressure or heart rate. Furthermore, coadministration of 21 (at the maximally effective dose of 2.5 mg/kg) does not significantly alter sibutramine’s ability to reduce food intake. Consequently, combining 5-HT1A activation with NA transport inhibition has two important attributes. First of all, it has the potential of preventing an increased sympathetic activity resulting from central increases in noradrenergic transmission produced by dual NA/5-HT reuptake inhibitors such as sibutramine. Second, the 5-HT1A activation may also contribute to hypophagia efficacy in combination with NA transporter blockade, through postsynaptic 5-HT1A receptor activity. Moreover it is additionally able to reduce food intake through the removal of tonic inhibition on spontaneous noradrenergic cell firing mediated by presynaptic 5-HT1A receptors.(108)

    5-HT1A and Urogenital Response

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Bladder dysfunction is characterized by impaired bladder sensation, increased bladder capacity, decreased bladder contractility, and increased residual urine. In several animal species, 5-HT is an important neurotransmitter that is also involved in the regulation of the micturition reflex and urinary incontinence. In addition to the central role of 5-HT, it also has a peripheral role with regard to bladder function.(109) In humans and in animals 5-HT exhibits excitatory effects in both nonstimulated and electrically stimulated detrusor strips.(110) While regulation of serotonergic receptors is considered a promising strategy for treating lower urinary tract symptoms, clinically available drugs have not been developed yet.(111) The lumbosacral autonomic and the sphincter motor nuclei (Onuf’s nuclei) receive a dense serotonergic input, and the descending bulbospinal pathway to the urinary bladder is essentially an inhibitory circuit, where serotonin represents a key neurotransmitter. Ligands acting at 5-HT1A receptors are able to modify lower urinary tract function and have effects on both the external urethral sphincter (EUS) and external anal sphincter.(112) Intravenous (iv) or intracerebroventricular (icv) injection of 1 is able to activate the micturition reflex, inducing an increase in the frequency of isovolumic bladder contractions. Conversely it was shown that 1 induces periodic EUS relaxation during voiding in urethane-anesthetized chronic spinal cord injured rats and that this causes an increase in micturition volume, a decrease in bladder capacity, and an increase in voiding efficiency. All these actions were mediated via 5-HT1A receptors as demonstrated by the observation that they were reversed by 29, suggesting the possibility that phasic relaxation depends upon descending serotonergic stimulation of 5-HT1A receptors. However, a direct excitatory effect of 1 on the bladder cannot be excluded because this agent can enhance spontaneous contractions of isolated bladder strips prepared from rats with chronic bladder outlet obstruction.(113) Developing 5-HT1A agonists with a preferential action on micturition reflex could provide a therapeutic tool for studying bladder dysfunction.

    5-HT1A and Cancer

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Serotonin exhibits multiple non-neural functions involved in essential hypertension, early embryogenesis, and follicle maturation and behavior.(24) It also acts as a growth factor on several types of nontumoral cells, and recently it was found to be related to oncogenes.(114) Depending on the tumor type, either 5-HT2 (carcinoid tumors) or 5-HT1 receptor antagonists are able to inhibit the 5-HT-induced increase in tumor growth. Growth-stimulatory activity of 5-HT in carcinoid valve disease and pancreatic carcinoid cells has been reported. Serotonin has also been proposed to take part in the autocrine loops of growth factors contributing to cell proliferation in tumors such as small cell lung carcinoma (SCLC).(114) SCLC is a very aggressive and metastatic tumor often associated with tobacco smoking; SCLC cells express neuronal proteins like voltage-dependent Ca2+ channels and nicotinic receptors. They also produce and release peptides like bombesin and insulin-like growth factor 1 which can establish an autocrine mitogenic loop. Moreover, it was shown that 5-HT is contained in and released from the SCLC cell lines NCI-N-592 and GLC-8. It is also mitogenic for SCLC cells and may therefore behave as an autocrine factor. Since this mitogenic effect of 5-HT appears to be important in controlling tumor growth, the 5-HT receptor subtype(s) present in SCLC cells were characterized and the involvement of 5-HT1D receptors into the mitogenic effects on SCLC cells was demonstrated.(115)
    Serotonin also may be involved in prostate cancer (PC), the most frequently diagnosed invasive cancer and the leading cause of cancer-related death among males in a number of countries.(116) Mounting evidence indicates that neuroendocrine cells play a role in prostatic disease. Neuroendocrine cells populate both normal and malignant prostate tissues and can synthesize, store, and release growth factors, as well as biogenic amines, 5-HT, DA, and other neurotransmitter-related substances.(117) An increase in the number of neuroendocrine cells is related to tumor progression.(118) Whether an increase in neuroendocrine cell secretory products as well as their synthesis and metabolism contribute to tumor progression remains to be determined. On the basis of these observations as well as the role of 5-HT as a growth factor for several types of nontumor and tumor cells, the expression of 5-HT receptor subtypes in PC-3 cells and in human hormone refractory prostate cancer tissue was investigated using immunohistochemical and Western blot techniques. Moreover, the effect of several 5-HTRs antagonists on PC-3 cells was evaluated.(119) It was also verified that the 5-HT1A receptor is involved in the proliferation of human tumor cells, but while the functional role of 5-HT1A receptor is well characterized in neural cells, it remains still poorly understood elsewhere.(114)
    In particular, signal transduction of 5-HT1A receptor is complex and the exact mechanism of action is yet to be determined. However, this receptor subtype differs significantly from most other 5-HT receptors and exhibits a substantial similarity to adrenergic receptors (α 1,2 and β 1,2); this may explain why a number of adrenergic agents, including propranolol and pindolol, bind to the 5-HT1A receptor with high affinity. Previously, 5-HT1A antagonists and serotonin-uptake inhibitors were reported to inhibit the growth of three different prostatic tumor cell lines, PC-3, DU-145, and LNCaP, in vitro. The same agents inhibited proliferation of PC-3 xenografted subcutaneously in athymic nude mice.(114) These results once again prove the implication of 5-HT in the growth of prostate carcinoma cells and indicate the 5-HT1A receptor as a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of PC. Identification of new therapeutic strategies is very important in particular for treating hormone-refractory PC. The localization and mRNA expression in (i) primary PC with clinical progression, (ii) PC metastases, and (iii) PC cell lines have been identified. Furthermore, the effects of serotonin and different 5-HT1A antagonists on proliferation of the PC cell lines in vitro were also examined together for the characterization and expression at the cellular level of 5-HT1A receptors in PC tissue, PC cell lines, and PC metastases. As demonstrated in experiments performed on Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cells expressing 5-HT1A receptors, the activation of the receptor-stimulated ERK1/2 occurred via Gi. By use of the same model system, it was also shown that the signaling downstream of the 5-HT1A receptor efficiently activates the PI3K/Akt signal transduction pathway promoting cell survival.(120) This finding suggested that this heterologous expression system closely resembles the physiological function of this receptor in other systems. In order to improve the current knowledge of the mechanistic involvement of 5-HT in cell survival, it was shown that the PI3K/Akt pathway activates NF-κB downstream of 5-HT1A receptor stimulation by degradation of the inhibitory subunit IκBa. This event allows NF-κB nuclear translocation, leading to inhibition of caspase-3 activity. The functional antagonism between PI3K/Akt and ERK signaling on NF-κB activation has already been described in studies reporting the effects of platelet-derived growth factor on cell survival. Platelet-derived growth factor receptor-stimulated NF-κB exerted both pro- and antiapoptotic roles; apoptosis is induced by the Raf/MAPK pathway, while antiapoptosis is dependent on the PI3K/Akt pathway.(120)
    Starting from these data, the antiproliferative activity of 1-naphthylpiperazine derivatives acting as selective 5-HT1A ligands was investigated. 1-Naphthylpiperazines were already described as able to block skin cancer induction likely because of an apoptotic mechanism.(121)
    Two of the newly synthesized derivatives (46 and 47, Figure 15) were selected in order to elucidate the mechanism responsible for the observed antiproliferative effect. Compounds 46 and 47 did not induce any apoptotic effect in PC-3 cells when compared with the same cell line treated with topotecan, a topoisomerase I inhibitor employed as positive control.
    Similar to 18 (Figure 6) and 1 (Figure 3), two compounds that did not induce any growth inhibition or apoptotic effects in PC-3 cells, no significant perturbation of cell cycle was observed when cells were treated with either 46 or 47. On the other hand, the treatment with topotecan for 24 h induced an increase of cells in G2-M phase and the appearance of a sub-G1 peak, thus indicating a subpopulation of apoptotic cells. Moreover, a complete disruption of cell cycle kinetics with many cells in sub-G1 was observed after 48 and 72 h of treatment.(121)
    MAPK and Akt are apparently the most relevant pathways among the quite complex intracellular signaling by which serotonin induces mitogenesis. Furthermore, MAPK and Akt are directly connected to the signaling pathways of 5-HT1A receptors. On this basis, the effects of 1, 18, 46, 47, and topotecan on the activation of MAPK and Akt were evaluated in PC-3 cells by Western blotting. Treatment with compounds 46, 47, and topotecan did not reduce basal MAPK phosphorylation; on the contrary all three compounds induced a complete inhibition of Akt phosphorylation. The lack of effect on the phosphorylation of MAPK could be explained considering that in the PC-3 cells the MAPK signal is constitutively activated because of a KRAS mutation.(121) Moreover, recent studies about the role of α1 and 5-HT1A receptors in prostate cancer seem to validate this target.
    Some 1,4-dioxane derivatives (compounds 48–50, Figure 15), characterized by full or partial agonism at 5-HT1A receptor and associated with an antagonist profile toward all three α1 receptor subtypes, when tested in human PC-3 prostate cancer cells showed antiproliferative and cytotoxic activities that were not affected by administration of the 5-HT1A antagonist 28 (Figure 9). This indicates that their potent 5-HT1A agonist activity was not in contrast to their anticancer activity.(122)
    Finally, this latter evidence as well as the inhibitory effect on Akt activity (associated with prosurvival signaling in cancer cells) shown by compounds 46 and 47 can explain the anticancer activity of 5-HT1A ligands. Further studies could be really useful to shed more light on the mechanism of action of the analyzed compounds that could represent new interesting leads as antiproliferative agents in prostatic cancer.

    Perspectives

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    It is clear that because of the multiplicity of functions, the 5-HT1A receptor is involved in a vast array of physiological and pathophysiological processes. Recent research advances have shown that many effects mediated by the 5-HT1A receptor remain largely unknown, and serotonergic modulation through this receptor appears promising for the development of novel therapeutic approaches for the treatment of many functional disorders from CNS to cancer. The intense research by medicinal chemists has allowed the identification of various classes of 5-HT1A receptor ligands, and there has been an ongoing effort to develop more selective 5-HT1A serotoninergic ligands(123-127) in order to have novel pharmacological tools that could improve our knowledge of the signal transduction mechanisms. A limitation of many 5-HT1A ligands is their undesired high affinity for other receptor subtypes such as the dopaminergic D2 receptor and α1-adrenoceptor.(34)
    Furthermore the use of some prototypical 5-HT1A agonists and antagonists has led to meaningful insight into the pathophysiological role of 5-HT1A receptor. It soon became clear that the 5-HT1A receptor is involved in many diseases and also that activation of this receptor would have beneficial effects on some unwanted side effects of antipsychotic drugs. As reported in this perspective, the identification of some potent and selective 5-HT1A receptor ligands led to the definition of newer therapeutic areas. In fact among the selective agonists, repinotan and 45 demonstrated anti-ischemic properties, whereas 12 showed remarkable analgesic properties. The 5-HT1A agonist component of 38 and pardoprunox has been shown to exert beneficial effects on levodopa-induced dyskinesia. A really interesting and emerging aspect could be represented by in-depth characterization of agonist intrinsic activity. In fact, many 5-HT1A agonists have been characterized only in comparison with 1 which also shows, in some biological systems, partial agonism compared to the native agonist 5-HT. Therefore, the evaluation in different in vitro and in vivo models of 5-HT1A receptor activation will give an accurate characterization of agonistic properties. It is important to note that regarding the involvement of 5-HT1A receptors in different pathologic conditions, the therapeutic role of 5-HT1A full or partial agonists seems to be more relevant than that of 5-HT1A antagonists, which in many cases are used as a tool to verify the efficacy of 5-HT1A agonists. Although some of the discussed agents will not reach the market as new drugs, they were shown to be powerful tools for elucidation of molecular mechanisms in which the 5-HT1A receptor is involved (Table 1).
    Table 1. 5-HT1A Ligands in Pharmacological Development
    Several chemical classes are already known for their high affinity toward these receptors, and from a chemical point of view, they can be subdivided into different classes (i.e., aminotetralins, indolylalkylamines, ergolines, aporphines, arylpiperazines). Among them, one of the most studied and recurring chemical motifs present in many molecules, also reported in Table 1 as new therapeutic tools acting on 5-HT1A receptor, is the long-chain arylpiperazines (LCAPs) one.(35) In these derivatives, the arylpiperazine moiety as tail of the molecule and the heterocyclic head are separated by a (CH2)n spacer attached to N-4 of the piperazine moiety. In the aryl position a substituted phenyl is typically located while the heterocyclic nucleus is an amide or imide. The chain length (n) can influence affinity and selectivity. When n = 4, optimal affinity is associated with a terminus that contains a heteroarylamide; when n = 2, alkylamides seem optimal.(135, 136) Although long-chain arylpiperazines typically possess an amide or imide moiety at or near the chain terminus, neither the amide nor the imide moiety is required for binding; that is, the terminus may be a phenyl or some other aromatic group.(135) Moreover the aromatic ring of the arylpiperazine scaffold is typically a substituted phenyl or heteroaromatic moiety (e.g., 2-pyrimidinyl). It is interesting to underline, however, that the presence of an oxygen atom at the phenyl 2-position (e.g., 2-methoxyphenyl) usually, but not always, imparts antagonist character. 2-Methoxyphenylpiperazine derivatives with structural similarity to 13, such as 16 and 18, were the first novel agents shown to possess 5-HT1A antagonist activity.(135) Compound 40 (Figure 14) is another arylpiperazine derivative that has been successfully used as a 5-HT1A ligand. Structurally related agents such as 11 (Figure 4), 21, and 26(137) (Figure 8) have been developed, and some of these are currently in clinical trials (Table 1) in order to explore their therapeutic potential.(135) Hundreds of arylpiperazine derivatives have been synthesized, but many are nonselective and bind other 5-HT, dopamine, and adrenergic receptors. The significance of the respective parts of the LCAP structures on the 5-HT1A receptor affinity, intrinsic activity, and selectivity has been the subject of many structure–activity relationship (SAR) studies involving variation of the aromatic systems at the “head” and “tail” of the structure with the length of the methylene linker and with the replacement of the amide bond with other functions.(138) A large number of SAR studies revealed the role of individual fragments, essential for high affinity for 5-HT1A sites and selectivity for other receptors.
    In conclusion, it is evident that this old target is currently an interesting challenge for medicinal chemists, and continuing research could yield new therapeutic agents and shed more light on the molecular mechanisms that involve this receptor. At the same time, the development of new molecules that act as selective 5-HT1A agents could be useful to validate this therapeutic target in many pathologic conditions where its therapeutic role is still unclear. Finally, the long-chain arylpiperazines (LCAPs) motif could be explored further in order to obtain more selective and efficient 5-HT1A agents. In addition, it would be highly desirable to develop new chemical scaffolds that can act selectively on the 5-HT1A receptor subtype.

    Note Added After ASAP Publication

    ARTICLE SECTIONS

    Abbreviations Used

    BDNF

    brain-derived neurotrophic factor

    CA1

    area of hippocampus filled with densely packed pyramidal cells

    CHO

    Chinese hamster ovary

    COS-1

    fibroblast-like cells derived from kidney of the African green monkey

    CREB

    cAMP response element-binding protein

    DMH

    dorsomedial hypothalamus

    DU145

    human prostate cancer cell line

    EPS

    extrapyramidal symptoms

    EUS

    external urethral sphincter

    HSDD

    hypoactive sexual desire disorder

    IELT

    intravaginal ejaculatory latency time

    LCAP

    long-chain arylpiperazine

    LID

    L-DOPA-induced dyskinesia

    LNCaP

    androgen-sensitive human prostate adenocarcinoma cell line

    MR

    medullary raphe

    MPTP

    1-methyl-4-phenyl-1,2,3,6-tetrahydropyridine

    NRP

    raphe pallidus nuclei

    PC

    prostate cancer

    PC-3

    human prostate cancer cell line

    PFC

    prefrontal cortex

    SCLC

    small cell lung carcinoma

    SSRI

    serotonin reuptake inhibitor

    TM

      Nichols, D. E.; Nichols, C. D. Serotonin receptors Chem. Rev. 2008, 108, 1614– 1641

      1
      Serotonin Receptors
      Nichols, David E.; Nichols, Charles D.
      Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2008), 108 (5), 1614-1641CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
      A review on phylogeny, structural features, oligomerization, classification and functions of serotonin receptors.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXlslOisL8%253D&md5=55b70829f6be71cbfe4de05c5ef665d8
    2. 2
      Fredriksson, R.; Lagerström, M. C.; Lundin, L. G.; Schiöth, H. B. The G-protein-coupled receptors in the human genome form five main families. Phylogenetic analysis, paralogon groups, and fingerprints Mol. Pharmacol. 2003, 63 (6) 1256– 1272
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2
      The G-protein-coupled receptors in the human genome form five main families. Phylogenetic analysis, paralogon groups, and fingerprints
      Fredriksson, Robert; Lagerstrom, Malin C.; Lundin, Lars-Gustav; Schioth, Helgi B.
      Molecular Pharmacology (2003), 63 (6), 1256-1272CODEN: MOPMA3; ISSN:0026-895X. (American Society for Pharmacology and Experimental Therapeutics)
      The superfamily of G-protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) is very diverse in structure and function and its members are among the most pursued targets for drug development. We identified more than 800 human GPCR sequences and simultaneously analyzed 342 unique functional nonolfactory human GPCR sequences with phylogenetic analyses. Our results show, with high bootstrap support, five main families, named glutamate, rhodopsin, adhesion, frizzled/taste2, and secretin, forming the GRAFS classification system. The rhodopsin family is the largest and forms four main groups with 13 subbranches. Positions of the GPCRs in chromosomal paralogons regions indicate the importance of tetraploidizations or local gene duplication events for their creation. We also searched for "fingerprint" motifs using Hidden Markov Models delineating the putative inter-relationship of the GRAFS families. We show several common structural features indicating that the human GPCRs in the GRAFS families share a common ancestor. This study represents the first overall map of the GPCRs in a single mammalian genome. Our novel approach of analyzing such large and diverse sequence sets may be useful for studies on GPCRs in other genomes and divergent protein families.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXkt1Shu7k%253D&md5=504ea873ee8469cd0b6016bc94943836
    3. 3
      Kobilka, B. K.; Frielle, T.; Collins, S.; Yang-Feng, T.; Kobilka, T. S.; Francke, U.; Lefkowitz, R. J.; Caron, M. G. An intronless gene encoding a potential member of the family of receptors coupled to guanine nucleotide regulatory proteins Nature 1987, 329, 75– 79
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3
      An intronless gene encoding a potential member of the family of receptors coupled to guanine nucleotide regulatory proteins
      Kobilka, Brian K.; Frielle, Thomas; Collins, Sheila; Yang-Feng, Theresa; Kobilka, Tong Sun; Francke, Uta; Lefkowitz, Robert J.; Caron, Marc G.
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (1987), 329 (6134), 75-9CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836.
      A DNA fragment from a human genomic library was isolated, cloned, and sequenced. The fragment (G-21) cross-hybridizes with a full-length B2-adrenergic probe at reduced stringency. The gene is intronless, and contains an uninterrupted long open reading frame which encodes a putative protein in the expected structural features of a G-protein-coupled receptor. The G-21 locus was localized to chromosome 5. The corresponding mRNA of 6000 nucleotides was most abundant in lymphatic tissues including lymph node, spleen, and thymus. This mRNA was also expressed in gut, muscle, and kidney but not in lung, heart, adrenal gland, and placenta.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Charest, A.; Wainer, B. H.; Albert, P. R. Cloning and differentiation-induced expression of a murine serotonin1A receptor in a septal cell line J. Neurosci. 1993, 13, 5164– 5171
      [CAS], Google Scholar
      6
      Cloning and differentiation-induced expression of a murine serotonin1A receptor in a septal cell line
      Charest, Alain; Wainer, Bruce H.; Albert, Paul R.
      Journal of Neuroscience (1993), 13 (12), 5164-71CODEN: JNRSDS; ISSN:0270-6474.
      A neuronal cell model endogenously expressing the 5-HT1A receptor, in which to study the function and regulation of this gene, has yet to be identified. The authors examd. murine SN-48 cells, a septum x neuroblastoma fusion cell line that proliferates in a nondifferentiated state but can be induced to differentiate into neurofilament-pos. cells following 24-96 h treatment with 10 μM retinoic acid in low serum. Northern blot anal. demonstrated the presence of a single 10.9 kilobase (kb) 5-HT1A receptor RNA species in differentiated SN-48 cells, which was not detected in undifferentiated SN-48 cells. The presence of receptor RNA in differentiated SN-48 cells correlated with the appearance of functional responses (i.e., pertussis toxin-sensitive inhibition of cAMP accumulation) to 5-HT1A agonists in differentiated but not in undifferentiated cells. To verify that the large 10.9 kb RNA species in SN-48 cells truly corresponded to the mouse 5-HT1A receptor RNA, a cDNA fragment from differentiated SN-48 cells was used to clone the corresponding mouse brain cDNA. The 2.4 kb cDNA contained a single open reading frame that displayed high (>85% predicted amino acid identity) homol. to the human and rat 5-HT1A receptor genes. When transfected into receptor-neg. Ltk- cells, this cDNA was found to direct expression of a murine 5-HT1A receptor. Thus, the authors conclude that upon differentiation SN-48 cells express RNA encoding functional 5-HT1A receptors. The SN-48 septal cells will provide a useful cellular model system for investigating aspects of neuronal differentiation leading to the development of sensitivity to serotonergic input.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

    10. 10
      Paila, Y. D.; Chattopadhyay, A. The human serotonin1A receptor expressed in neuronal cells: toward a native environment for neuronal receptors Cell. Mol. Neurobiol. 2006, 26, 925– 942
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      10
      The Human Serotonin1A Receptor Expressed in Neuronal Cells: Toward a Native Environment for Neuronal Receptors
      Paila, Yamuna Devi; Chattopadhyay, Amitabha
      Cellular and Molecular Neurobiology (2006), 26 (4-6), 925-942CODEN: CMNEDI; ISSN:0272-4340. (Springer)
      The serotonin1A (5-HT1A) receptor is an important representative of G-protein coupled family of receptors. It is the most extensively studied among the serotonin receptors, and appears to be involved in various behavioral and cognitive functions. We report here the pharmacol. and functional characterization of the human serotonin1A receptor stably expressed in HN2 cell line, which is a hybrid cell line between hippocampal cells and mouse neuroblastoma. Our results show that serotonin1A receptors in HN2-5-HT1AR cells display ligand-binding properties that closely mimic binding properties obsd. with native receptors. We further demonstrate that the differential discrimination of G-protein coupling by the specific agonist and antagonist, a hallmark of the native receptor, is maintained for the receptor in HN2-5-HT1AR cells. Importantly, the serotonin1A receptor in HN2-5-HT1AR cells shows efficient downstream signalling by reducing cellular cAMP levels. We conclude that serotonin1A receptors expressed in HN2-5-HT1AR cells represent a useful model system to study serotonin1A receptor biol., and is a potential system for solubilization and purifn. of the receptor in native-like membrane environment.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28Xhtleksb3I&md5=7f0691bdb52e26100e616eff5e3cd316
    11. 11
      Pucadyil, T. J.; Kalipatnapu, S.; Chattopadhyay, A. The serotonin1A receptor: a representative member of the serotonin receptor family Cell. Mol. Neurobiol. 2005, 25, 553– 580
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      11
      The serotonin1A receptor: a representative member of the serotonin receptor family
      Pucadyil, Thomas J.; Kalipatnapu, Shanti; Chattopadhyay, Amitabha
      Cellular and Molecular Neurobiology (2005), 25 (3/4), 553-580CODEN: CMNEDI; ISSN:0272-4340. (Springer)
      A review. Serotonin is an intrinsically fluorescent biogenic amine that acts as a neurotransmitter and is found in a wide variety of sites in the central and peripheral nervous system. Serotonergic signaling appears to play a key role in the generation and modulation of various cognitive and behavioral functions. Serotonin exerts its diverse actions by binding to distinct cell surface receptors which have been classified into many groups. The serotonin1A (5-HT1A) receptor is the most extensively studied of the serotonin receptors and belongs to the large family of 7-transmembrane domain G-protein coupled receptors. The tissue and sub-cellular distribution, structural characteristics, signaling of the serotonin1A receptor and its interaction with G-proteins are discussed. The pharmacol. of serotonin1A receptors is reviewed in terms of binding of agonists and antagonists and sensitivity of their binding to guanine nucleotides. Membrane biol. of 5-HT1A receptors is presented using the bovine hippocampal serotonin1A receptor as a model system. The ligand binding activity and G-protein coupling of the receptor is modulated by membrane cholesterol thereby indicating the requirement of cholesterol in maintaining the receptor organization and function. This, along with the reported detergent resistance characteristics of the receptor, raises important questions on the role of membrane lipids and domains in the function of this receptor.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXnslyrurw%253D&md5=4bf849e2150b81a4525ec381130b70f3

      Gether, U.; Kobilka, B. K. G protein-coupled receptors. II. Mechanism of agonist activation J. Biol. Chem. 1998, 273, 17979– 17982
      Google Scholar
      There is no corresponding record for this reference.
    13. 13
      Kalipatnapu, S.; Chattopadhyay, A. Membrane organization and function of the serotonin1A receptor Cell. Mol. Neurobiol. 2007, 27 (8) 1097– 1116
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      13
      Membrane Organization and Function of the Serotonin1A Receptor
      Kalipatnapu, Shanti; Chattopadhyay, Amitabha
      Cellular and Molecular Neurobiology (2007), 27 (8), 1097-1116CODEN: CMNEDI; ISSN:0272-4340. (Springer)
      A review. (1) The serotonin1A receptor is a G-protein coupled receptor involved in several cognitive, behavioral, and developmental functions. It binds the neurotransmitter serotonin and signals across the membrane through its interactions with heterotrimeric G-proteins. (2) Lipid-protein interactions in membranes play an important role in the assembly, stability, and function of membrane proteins. The role of membrane environment in serotonin1A receptor function is beginning to be addressed by exploring the consequences of lipid manipulations on the ligand binding and G-protein coupling of serotonin1A receptors, the ability to functionally solubilize the serotonin1A receptor, and the factors influencing the membrane organization of the serotonin1A receptor. (3) Recent developments involving the application of detergent-based and detergent-free approaches to understand the membrane organization of the serotonin1A receptor under conditions of ligand activation and modulation of membrane lipid content, with an emphasis on membrane cholesterol, are described.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhtFWluro%253D&md5=6ed5e145c5474a3f6ce12ba293495318
